prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: ISM species distribution in G11.94-0.62B (Tuning 1)
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: This Science Goal is designed to map several spectral lines detected towards both G11.94-0.62B and G16.871-2.154, using a Nyquist-sampled pointed mosaic, in the ALMA Band 3 84-88 GHz and 96-100 GHz range at an average spectral resolution of ~1.8km/s.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: Since this justification applies similarly to all 8 Science Goals it has been generalised accordingly. The Observation Tool (OT) suggested supplementing the 12-m array observations with the ACA. We aim to resolve structure in our sources at the combination of compact (SiO and CH3OH masers) and extended scales, known to be present in star-forming regions. Based on our ATCA observations, we do not anticipate very extended angular structures and so have set a value of 20 arcsec (close to the maximum resolvable scale of the array) in our Science Goals. These previous observations also constrain the maximum continuum spectral flux density to be of order 10 mJy/Beam and compact, but since the continuum is generally absent in our sources and we do not aim to study it in this project, we have left the peak continuum flux density blank. The expected lowest linewidths in our sources of ~ 3.3 km/s are derived from our single-dish observations with the Mopra radio telescope. However, we decide to tune the OT spectral setup resolution to approximately twice better than this, to aid in reducing potential line confusion (in the few cases where more than one molecular line belonging to separate species fall within ~ 1 MHz of each other) and help resolve self-absorption features, up to the limit of the normal maximum correlator bandwidth of 12 MB/s, yielding 2 resolutions per FWHM. While this is clearly not enough to properly resolve the hyperfine components featured in some of our lines, this is not an issue as this project is more concerned in mapping the spatial distribution of different species (and their isotopologues) and calculating total abundances, rather than detailed spectral line analysis. We choose to compromise on obtaining a reasonable improvement (up to one order of magnitude) over potential single-dish spatial resolutions with Mopra, while avoiding driving the total project time into unreasonable territory, by selecting a desired angular resolution of 3 arcsec. Warm-up chemical species feature lower abundances and hence weaker lines compared to tracer species, making them best observable at high-resolution. Since we are interested in obtaining an even sensitivity in our observations over an extended area up to 90 arcsec in width, we choose to use the option to mosaic a Nyquist-sampled rectangular field of pointings. Due to the additive mosaicing, LO1 placement and general bandwidth setup limitations of the ALMA Cycle 2 systems in Band 3, our setup required us to spread out our project over 8 Science Goals in order to account for both our sources at 4 separate tunings. Importantly however, this has enabled us to cover almost all our previously detected spectral lines (but all molecular species, many of which are tracers of physical properties, dense gas and star formation) that fall into the ALMA Band 3 range. Although we have specified a line peak flux density of 0.60 mJy/Beam in our expected source properties (yielding a SNR of only 0.15), most of the spectral lines we wish to resolve are in fact at least one order of magnitude brighter than this lower limit and so this reported value does not undermine the feasibility of our project to the extent that it may appear on paper. On the other hand, the relevant science parameters for our source setups give a sensitivity of ~ 4 mJy as required to achieve our Science Goals, while for our spectral setup, the sensitivity calculated using our aggregate bandwidth of ~ 3.75 GHz amounts to ~ 0.05 mJy, seemingly more than appropriate for meeting our requested line sensitivity.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: ISM species distribution in G11.94-0.62B (Tuning 4)
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: This Science Goal is designed to map several spectral lines detected towards both G11.94-0.62B and G16.871-2.154, using a Nyquist-sampled pointed mosaic, with particular focus on complex molecules in the ALMA Band 3 109-111 GHz range, at an average spectral resolution of ~1.55km/s.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: Recent observations using the Australia Telescope Compact Array and Mopra 22-m radio telescope (cf. Balnozan et al. 2014, in prep.) have detected a large number of complex organic molecular species towards two 'millimetre-only' sources identified by Hill et al. (2005) in a 1.2-mm continuum survey (previously assumed devoid of typical indicators of massive star formation, such as methanol maser and radio continuum, cf. C2102-2009JULS PI: T. Hill), suggesting they may in fact be massive star-forming cores in their earliest warm-up stages. Complementing our current observations with the high spectral resolution capabilities of the ALMA Cycle 2 systems would allow us to image the extended and extensive molecular line emission, while providing confirmation of methanol maser (over thermal) emission necessary for distinguishing between early-stage massive star formation and lower-mass objects. These results have the potential to further scientific understanding of the astrochemistry distinguishing low and high-mass star formation, the possible relation between mm-only radio sources and massive protostars, and produce data relevant to creating chemical timelines of their early evolution.

prp:PrincipalInvestigator.prp:organisation: School of Physics , University of New South Wales

prp:CoInvestigator.prp:organisation: School of Physics, New South Wales, University of
